BasicDescription.Title: Crossing Continents
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Namibia: Is President Sam Nujoma taking his country down the same road as Zimbabwe? Rosie Goldsmith travels around this vast country in search of the answer to that question.

Namibia
When Sam Nujoma, President of Namibia, shook his finger and railed at Tony Blair at the Earth summit in September the world took notice. Calling Blair a colonialist and blaming the British for the ills of Southern Africa he staunchly defended his friend Robert Mugabe's right to deal with white farmers as he saw fit and declared that Namibia doesn't need western aid.
Is Nujoma taking his country down the same road as Zimbabwe? Rosie Goldsmith travels around this vast country in search of the answer to that question.

BasicDescription.Title: Home Truths
BasicDescription.Synopsis: John Peel takes another wry look at the foibles of family life .

BasicDescription.Title: The Food Programme
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Sheila Dillon looks at kitchen gadgets, from the most useful to the most spectacularly useless, and investigates the latest items of kitchen paraphernalia. .

Gadgets
This week, Sheila will discover which are the most useful and most useless kitchen gadgets ever invented and what bits of cookery kit are being dreamed up by the gadget maestros in their work shops in Northern Italy.
.

BasicDescription.Title: The Archers
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Simon has some important news.

BasicDescription.Title: Midnight News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: Moral Notes
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Love: Simon Brett explores how the Victorians perfected the use of popular song as a vehicle of values, morality and beliefs. Then Weather, Bells On Sunday and Sailing By.

The Victorians perfected the use of popular song as a way to reflect values, morality and beliefs. It is an art which has never lost its ability to act as a mirror to society, as Simon Brett reveals in his exploration of morality in note form from the early 19th century until today.
Part 3, Love
The Victorians edged the concept of Love in lace. Under their tutelage it grew to an ideal to be aspired to - at least in public. But behind the sentiment lies a reality not that different from our own, and then, as now it is a morality which is well documented in song.
Then Weather, Bells On Sunday and Sailing By.

BasicDescription.Title: Shipping Forecast
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest Shipping Forecast.

BasicDescription.Title: As BBC World Service
BasicDescription.Synopsis: BBC Radio 4 joins the BBC World Service for a selection of news and current affairs, arts and science programmes. BBC Radio 4 resumes at ....

BasicDescription.Title: Radio 4 Open Up
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Includes a News Summary, the latest Shipping and Inshore Waters forecasts, and Prayer For The Day.

BasicDescription.Title: Farming Today
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Agricultural news and features presented by Sarah Mukherhee.

BasicDescription.Title: Today
BasicDescription.Synopsis: With Sarah Montague and James Naughtie. Includes Sports Desk at 6.25am, 7.25am and 8.25am; Weather at 6.55am and 7.55am; Thought For The Day at 7.45am.

BasicDescription.Title: Start The Week
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Andrew Marr and guests set the cultural agenda for the week.

BasicDescription.Title: Book Of The Week
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Peacemakers: By Margaret MacMillan. Part 1, The Delegates: For the first six months of 1919 Paris effectively became the capital of the world.

Peacemakers
By Margaret MacMillan, read by Jane Lapotaire.
Part 1, The Delegates:
For the first six months of 1919 Paris effectively became the capital of the world as the heads of state of over 30 countries gathered to try and create a new world order in the wake of the first world war.

BasicDescription.Title: Woman's Hour
BasicDescription.Synopsis: With Jenni Murray. Includes at 10.45am the drama Mary Hays In Love: Philippa Gregory introduces the love letters sent between Mary Hays and John Eccles.

With Jenni Murray. Includes at 10.45am the drama Mary Hays In Love:
Adapted for radio and introduced by Philippa Gregory.
Part One
Philippa Gregory introduces the love letters sent between the early feminist writer, Mary Hays, and her neighbour, John Eccles, in 1779. Mary and John are young, in love and forbidden to marry.
Mary Hays ...... Poppy Miller John Eccles ...... Nick Fletcher
director ...... Gaynor Macfarlane

BasicDescription.Title: Mapping The Town
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Leeds: Julian Richards explores how Leeds found itself ideally placed to move from little more than a river crossing, to the boomtown of the cloth industry and the industrial revolution.

BasicDescription.Title: Dr Finlay
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The Further Adventures Of A Black Bag. Miracle By Lestrange: When new fangled Alternative Medicine hits Levenford, Finlay and Cameron find they are losing all their patients, even Janet.

The Further Adventures Of A Black Bag
A further yarn about Scotland's most celebrated doctor in Sue Rodwell's new dramatisation of AJ Cronin's comic stories.
Miracle By Lestrange: When new fangled Alternative Medicine hits Levenford, Finlay and Cameron find they are losing all their patients, even Janet.
Dr Finlay ...... John Gordon Sinclair Dr Cameron ...... Brian Pettifer Janet ...... Celia Imrie Lestrange ...... David Bamber Annie Grant ...... Claire Neilson

BasicDescription.Title: News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news headlines from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: You And Yours
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Consumer news and discussion with John Waite and Winifred Robinson.

BasicDescription.Title: The World At One
BasicDescription.Synopsis: National and international news from BBC Radio 4. With reports from our correspondents worldwide. Presented by Nick Clarke.

BasicDescription.Title: Brain Of Britain 2002
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Chairman Robert Robinson presents the third semi-final, featuring contestants from the West and the North of England and Wales. .

A nationwide general knowledge contest in which listeners compete to become this year's Brain Of Britain.
Chairman Robert Robinson presents the third semi-final, featuring contestants from the West and the North of England and Wales.
The programme includes Beat The Brains in which listeners put their own questions to the contestants.
.

BasicDescription.Title: Afternoon Play
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Racer: By Kevin Fegan. A mix of poetry and interviews with riders and their families based on the famous Isle of Mann TT Races. The Racer is played by Paul McGann.

Racer: By Kevin Fegan
A mix of poetry and interviews with riders and their families based on the famous Isle of Mann TT Races. An exciting, high speed journey seen through the eyes of a racer lapping the circuit. Evocatively named landmarks remind the racer of triumphs, accidents and more poignantly of the people he has loved. The Racer is played by Paul McGann.

BasicDescription.Title: Money Box Live
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Paul Lewis and guests takes listeners' calls on a topical issue affecting personal finance. Call in on 0870 010 0444 [national rates].

BasicDescription.Title: The City
BasicDescription.Synopsis: By Hermann Hesse. A week of stories about cities and the experience of living in them begins with an archetypal fable of the birth and death of a city from Hesse's collection of fairy tales.

By Hermann Hesse
A week of stories about cities and the experience of living in them begins with an archetypal fable of the birth and death of a city from Hesse's collection of fairy tales, read by Andrew Hilton.

BasicDescription.Title: Herbs: Pure And Simple
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The Cabbage Family: Jekka McVicar travels to the Cotswolds to find out more about herbs and reveals some practical herbal remedies. She is joined by chef Raymond Blanc.

Programme 1: The Cabbage Family
Herb farmer Jekka McVicar travels to the Cotswolds to explore more about the magical world of herbs and reveal some practical herbal remedies. She is joined by world renowned chef Raymond Blanc.

BasicDescription.Title: Four Corners
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Gavin Esler and guests look behind the headlines to the international issues and cultures which shape the world.

BasicDescription.Title: PM
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Full coverage and analysis of the day's news, plus the sports headlines. Presented by Clare English and Carolyn Quinn.

BasicDescription.Title: Six O'Clock News
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.

BasicDescription.Title: I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Humphrey Lyttelton hosts the inimitable antidote to panel games. Usual suspects Tim Brooke-Taylor, Graeme Garden and Barry Cryer are this week joined by Tony Hawks. .

BasicDescription.Title: The Archers
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Chaba's feeling vulnerable.

BasicDescription.Title: Front Row
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Mark Lawson's guests include Barry Humphries, who discusses his memoir My Life As Me.

BasicDescription.Title: Mary Hays In Love
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Philippa Gregory introduces the love letters sent between the early feminist writer, Mary Hays, and her neighbour, John Eccles, in 1779.

Part One
Adapted for radio and introduced by Philippa Gregory.
Philippa Gregory introduces the love letters sent between the early feminist writer, Mary Hays, and her neighbour, John Eccles, in 1779. Mary and John are young, in love and forbidden to marry.

BasicDescription.Title: Rookie Reverends
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Alex Kirby meets the Church of England's new recruits. Carolyn Cooke and Liz Law are taking their first tentative steps into a demanding and sometimes hostile world.

The second of two programmes in which Alex Kirby meets the Church of England's new recruits. Carolyn Cooke and Liz Law are taking their first tentative steps into a demanding and sometimes hostile world. How will they cope with funerals, weddings and the general pressures of parish life? Both women talk openly about ambition, faith, doubts and fears.

BasicDescription.Title: Animal Farm
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Sue Broom explores the future of farming. The focus is on salmon where increasing emphasis on quality, and the prospect of genetically engineered fish are the main concerns.

Sue Broom continues to look at the science behind the future of Britain's livestock production. This week the focus is salmon where increasing emphasis on quality, and the prospect of genetically engineered fish are the main concerns.

BasicDescription.Title: The World Tonight
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Analysis of the day's national and international stories, including interviews with politicians and public figures.

BasicDescription.Title: Book At Bedtime
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Tiger In The Smoke: By Margery Allingham. Anton Lessor reads the evocative story of dangerous men in search of mysterious treasure in post war London. Tonight the Gaffer returns.

BasicDescription.Title: Today In Parliament
BasicDescription.Synopsis: A review of the day's events in Parliament.
